intro: Linum pubescens subsp. anisocalyx, commonly known as the hairy flax, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, blue to purple flowers that bloom in summer. The leaves are opposite, ovate, and covered in fine, soft hairs, giving the plant its common name. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in dry grasslands and rocky areas. This subspecies is closely related to other flax species and is valued for its ornamental appeal and historical use in textile production.
